content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy that provides a consistent but lower payoff over the risk of earning nothing for most rounds. Given my preference for security and predictability, and considering that this game has 75 rounds, I would go with strategy B. The reason is, even though choosing R would yield a higher payoff in some instances (if my opponent chooses B), the chances of that happening are not guaranteed. On the other hand, by choosing B consistently, I ensure a lower but steady payoff for every round. In the end, this strategy reduces the risk of earning nothing and provides a more predictable outcome. Thus, my choice is B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Since my objective is to earn a steady payoff over the long run, I will continue with strategy B in the next round as well. The reason for this is that even though choosing R would have resulted in a higher payoff in this particular instance (if my opponent chose R), it doesn't change the fact that in the majority of cases, choosing R will result in earning nothing. On the other hand, by continuing with strategy B, I ensure a lower but steady payoff for every round. Thus, my choice is B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this instance, I made a mistake by choosing strategy B when my opponent chose R. Since my objective is to earn a steady payoff over the long run and given that I made a mistake in the previous round, I will adjust my strategy slightly. Instead of sticking with one strategy (B) throughout the game, I will mix up my choices between R and B. This approach aims to balance the higher potential reward when choosing R (if my opponent continues with their current choice of R) while still ensuring a lower but steady payoff by occasionally choosing B. Thus, in this specific round, I choose R{R}.
